title: Ask me anything!! (About narrative (for Warwick, Urgot, Swain, Nunu & Willump, and Pantheon (VGUs)))
body:
Lol. If you want. {{sticker:slayer-pantheon-rainbows}}  Really, any narrative question is welcome.

It's League's 10 year anniversary and I've been a narrative writer on the Champion Update (and now Champions) team for 3 of them!! Gasp. It seems like a good time to look back, and also to pull back the curtain and show some of the things that excite us behind the scenes, so we can all be excited as players when the champions release. (Well. Never _all_. But you know.)

**Want to know what inspired individual lines?**
(My grandfather used to say, "[We're off like a dirty shirt!](https://vignette.wikia.nocookie.net/leagueoflegends/images/9/97/Nunu_238.ogg/revision/latest?cb=20180817190835)" whenever he drove me and my sister somewhere.)

**Want to see pitches and stories that are never released?**
They're probably bad, but I could find snippets! 

**Want to learn what the process is like writing champions, or how to get a job writing games?**
This comes up frequently, and every time the question is answered it disappears back into the depths of the Sinking City. 

I'll be here all day. Secretly, we're here every day! Thank you especially to you, the players on the boards, your passion for Story, Art, & Sound is _why_ I'm here. 

PS: If you'd prefer, tune in to [twitch and watch other narrative Rioters read selections from their favorite stories](https://www.twitch.tv/thelegendlarry)!

Reav3 also has a [Champions AMA going on Reddit](https://www.reddit.com/r/leagueoflegends/comments/di9yjx/got_questions_about_champions_ama/)!

A question about Swain and Noxus in general: why does Swain ignore the fact that LeBlanc is (heavily implied) to be part of the Trifarix?

I mean, she’s consistently trying to depose Swain, so why does he just straight up ignore her?

If Swain ignored her, he'd be dead. Swain keeps her close because he believes in his ability to manage the challenge. And, LeBlanc and Swain intrigue each other.

It's only hinted at in his backstory, but Swain killed LeBlanc with his own hand during a high society waltz... only for her to reappear again. This could scare him. This could enrage him. Or it could intrigue him.

So to repeat, LeBlanc and Swain intrigue each other.

Among many other things.

Thank you for the answer!

Now I’m really... intrigued.

Thanks for the AMA, love what you did with these champs, they're all in my top 10.

**Warwick:** he's mostly a rumor. He operates on the fringes of Zaun, which is already mostly fringes; there aren't many people around. Beyond that, there usually aren't survivors when he smells blood. But people hear the howl, and see the result. 

I think one person who definitely knows about Warwick is Baron Spindlow, since Warwick's been interfering with his operations (seen in the CG and the [Warwick short story](https://universe.leagueoflegends.com/en_US/story/warwick-color-story/); Boggin, the dude with the robo leg is your clue). Singed also knows at least about his origins. And would be most intrigued to learn of recent developments.

**Urgot:** Urgot's actions draw his followers, and his speeches after. He never directly recruits them. They organize themselves, somewhat. It's easy to think of him as a villain, but I think he has a really powerful message for the downtrodden. You're stronger than you know. You're stronger than _they_ know. You've had to be. Now _show them_.

**Swain:** Let's just say Swain had a head start, given who his parents were.

Hey, Interlocutioner. I'm a big fan of your work on reworks and have a few questions:

- This isn't meant to be a statement on the quality of the story (you did a great job on Pantheon) but why was the decision made to move away from Celestial Pantheon? I know quite a few people felt the 2016 take was unsatisfying and incomplete, and it certainly adds a quasi-Kratos archetype to League but I'd like to hear your thoughts on why the call was ultimately made to not explore the Celestial Pantheon instead? We have precious little insight on the mindset and motivations of Targon and Pantheon, out of all Aspects, was the one who never relinquished control and who could offer some insight  into celestial affairs with some nuance and who was himself extremely underdeveloped due to how much focus his previous bio placed on Atreus.

- Is Atreus' certainty regarding the evil of the "gods" something you'd like to challenge in the future? 

- What can you share about the implications of replacing/rebuilding War? What consequences are there to a human potentially becoming a Celestial? The way I've been interpreting it celestiality comes at a price, and I'd like to hear your thoughts on what that could mean for Atreus, champion of humanity, as he gradually becomes or is connected to something  other than humanity. Is that something Riot intends to explore?

- How do you imagine Pantheon would feel about beings like Ornn, Nasus or Morgana? Entities who, in spite of their power, have seemingly retreated for so long, even as people suffer without them. Or about ASol? Who is himself a victim of Targon's games?

- Any tidbits/cryptic hints you can give us about how Swain tricked the demon? 

- How was the process of writing Nunu like? He really does capture that feeling of childhood wonder, how did you go about "identifying" what makes something feel like "childhood"? 

For snippets, I'd love something about Swain and the demon (how they communicated before the deal or communicate now after it, how he copes with the power he now has)  or about Pantheon versus Aatrox. 

Thank you for doing this. Hope your current projects fare well.

We moved away from the Celestial because we found something compelling about the man who was burned away. It was really that simple. Sunny (Kindlejack on the boards) described how Atreus always stood up, and I asked myself... what if a man stood up from a blow that killed a god? What would that mean? Riot Scruffy also really wanted to know why Pantheon fought. What's behind the "one man army" fantasy that gameplay was working on?

I ended up writing a story sketch (really rough, meant-to-inspire-but-not-be-shippable flash fiction) examining this question. Having Atreus be interrogated by a vision of Pylas, demanding to know why he fought. Every answer he gives is revealed to be a fallacy, an excuse, and is torn away. Until (bear with me, this is bad and you're not supposed to see it):

> “I fight because I have no choice,” Atreus said, his fury rising. “Because I am mortal! All of us here on this mountain, we either fight or we wither away! Every time I’ve failed, every time I’ve struggled, it’s only reminded me that I can’t stop. That my battle is nothing compared to that of the grass and the wind. There is… no struggle for a god,” Atreus suddenly realized. “So what did I think I would do with your power? How did I think I could have it, and still be me? I wasted my strength, there on the mountain...”
> 
> “Finally, you speak the truth,” Pylas laughed in the voice of thousands, bringing forth a gush of blood onto his chin. “Now tell me, mortal who must fight. Why do we? Why do the Aspects?”
> 
> But before Atreus could answer, the golden light in Pylas’s eyes faded. And as they once again closed… Atreus finally opened his. 
> 
> The first thing he saw were the stars, shining weakly through the thin air and clouds, dimmer than they had ever been. As if a constellation were now missing.
> 
> It wasn’t until he felt a twist in his shoulder that Atreus looked down and finally realized, it was not a spear piercing through a god’s chest, spilling blood that could blot out the stars—but a demon blade through his. 

Atreus's certainty will definitely be challenged in the future. Leona wasn't necessarily wrong when she advised against fighting the barbarians, preferring to defend. Atreus is determined, in part, because of guilt. Because he knows he got Pylas killed.

For replacing/rebuilding War, yes! We're already exploring that, and there are many potential answers if you dig deep. The constellation starting to reappear. How Atreus can only access the powers through strength of will, how the weapon must ignite from what is within him. These are all clues, things you can interpret and spelling it all out would ruin the fun.  {{sticker:slayer-jinx-wink}} Seriously, my favorite narrative moment in video games was figuring out the KOTOR twist a few planets in. 

Re Ornn etc., how Atreus feels about the powerful is directly tied to what they do with that power, and why they seek it.

One tidbit I can give about Swain is that no one has correctly guessed what the darkness is that he sees yet.

Nunu's relationship with Lissandra is one of my favorite aspects of the character, and also one we've barely begun to explore. When I started on Nunu, previous lore placed him in the Frostguard and I had to figure out what that meant, and how it could be an interesting part of his story. I started to think of Lissandra as a Jadis/White Witch type character, at least when interacting with Nunu, _because he has something she wants_.

But I also think it's worth pointing out that Nunu trusts her, and quoting a snippet from one of my documents:

> Nunu is not: 

> Dumb (he’s a trusting dreamer, he sees the good in people—there’s a difference!!)

Note that Willump also has _his own_ relationship with Lissandra. Nunu has not ever (at least where I left him) interacted with Lissandra when Willump was there. They might be surprised to learn exactly what their best friend thinks.

As for the Russian Lissandra story, I'm afraid I have no news! All TBA.

Urgot is very public in his actions. With every chem-baron broken, he leaves a new mark on the city, turning the resulting chaos into a crucible. One day it will boil over. So the answer isn't that he's known to many or few. It's that this knowledge is _growing_.

> An idealist who seeks to lift the people of Zaun to a new level of understanding, [Viktor] believes that only by embracing a glorious evolution of technology can humanity’s full potential be realized.

Viktor, in a way, is concerned with similar things as Urgot, just couched in different words. "Potential" vs. "strength." There's a certain amount of absolutism to his belief, that technology is the only way forward to a bright future, a way to become better. You could perhaps imagine this is why Urgot still has one human arm. He would relish the opportunity to crush all of Viktor's machines, and Viktor himself in his bare hand. And then [say something super villain-y](https://vignette.wikia.nocookie.net/leagueoflegends/images/e/ed/Urgot.executeViktor.ogg/revision/latest?cb=20170807000909). Okay, here's the story behind another line:

> [They are called gods, but when they die, you cannot hear their howls above the wind.
](https://vignette.wikia.nocookie.net/leagueoflegends/images/7/79/Pantheon02.firstmove.05.ogg/revision/latest?cb=20190906064102)

While working on Pantheon, I read part of a manga set on Mt. Everest. Like, a volume right from the middle of the story, in a box of graphic novels on sale. What impressed me more than anything was the depiction of how... there's never a moment of silence or rest that high on a mountain. Scenes that otherwise looked peaceful and still would be betrayed by the sound of the wind, and by how desperately the people climbing the mountain had to fight to survive. That feeling became this line.

A pitch example. I actually like to be very open at the beginning of the champion development process, and create "thumbnails." One paragraph lore/archetype summaries that capture some of the things the team has been talking about, but take them further. 

This is a good example, one from Nunu. Because you might be able to see that while we didn't go with the pitch, many elements carried forward. Being from a tribe that roams the Freljord, having a power that Lissandra wants, etc. (For Nunu & Willump, I pitched ten thumbnails total, for what it's worth!)

> Pitch 5  - The Circus that Saved the World
> 
> Nunu and Willump belong to a troupe of performers that roams the Freljord in tinker carts, putting on shows in exchange for trinkets. (Think the circus, and Willump is the star “fierce animal who’s not really fierce” act.) After learning the truth about the troupe from his parents (they are gathering up relics to keep Lissandra from acquiring them, and summoning the Watchers), it isn’t long before the Frostguard arrives, and many are killed. Nunu and Willump escape the attack, stealing a shard of true ice from Lissandra that Nunu uses to make infinite snowballs. In Lissandra’s hands, it’s a far deadlier weapon, and she’ll do anything to get it back, along with everything else Nunu “stole.”
> 
> Future: Eluding Lissandra long enough to find Ashe

That might be a good segue into a discussion about our process. Riot does things differently from a lot of other companies. The designer, concept artist, and writer are all there from the beginning, brainstorming and trying to inspire each other. This is called DNA, because... Design, Narrative, and Art. Also, the whole deoxyribonucleotide thing. 

Typically, we'll start with some high level goals from Reav3 (and increasingly, a gameplay hook that's already proven promising, to avoid painful pivots later; if gameplay doesn't work, nothing does). With or without a gameplay hook, these might be as simple as, lighthearted female top laner. Or, sci-fi aesthetic, high agency marksman. From there, everyone starts pitching ideas back and forth, the more the better so we can discuss and get a broad view before narrowing down. This is called the "DISCOVERY" phase of DNA. For narrative, this is typically when you brainstorm different backstories, themes, story arcs, and maybe explore them in story sketch form to see what inspires others.

Once we have the general gameplay (what we call "pattern lock," we know what the champ wants to do to win, but not every ability), concept, and narrative in place, we start "IDEATION," really honing in on specifics. Going as deep as we can on one idea. For narrative, this means starting to write VO and finalize the character's personality, understand how that ties into gameplay and the broader themes in place, and communicating with other team members as they start to animate, explore VFX, etc.

From there, we'll enter pre-production (focusing on answering any in-game questions have arisen), and then production (just making the thing).

Hello. I have two questions I would like to ask:

* How knowledgeable is Swain about the history of the Noxian empire; specifically, how informed is he about the threat of Mordekaiser that looms from within Mitna Rachnun, and the members of the Black Rose cabal? Does he know how Noxus was originally begot by them?

* How aware is Willump of the threat that the Watchers pose, i.e. that they are trapped within the Howling Abyss, but slowly awakening? What does he think of Lissandra's intentions? And also, what is his opinion on the various Freljordian demigods that the tribespeople worship?

Swain is among the most knowledgeable about Mordekaiser, since he is knowledgeable about the Black Rose. This is the level of knowledge I'd leave it at, and let future stories decide more from there.

Willump knows a lot about the Watchers (his people sacrificed everything to lock them away), but I don't think he has thoughts about any of the demigods other than Anivia. They are very humanity focused. The yetis are older, more magical, less tied to the gods. Oh, and as for Lissandra.

Hey Interlocutioner, thanks for holding this AMA!

I am quite the Pantheon fan/main, so my questions will be solely focused around him and the narrative direction riot is taking with him. I've known Pantheon as the proud Stanpar warrior who joined the league because he got offended that there was an institute of war that did not think of him or his people. Now after all these years we finally again have a Pantheon who is a mortal man who will greet battle like an old friend. 
The divine Pantheon, aspect of war and so on was a completely cool idea that I really enjoyed. The issue that I feel comes from something like the god Pantheon is that there is no place for character growth or ability to relate to him. He was cool and badass simply for the sake of being badass. With the new Pantheon you reintroduced the human warrior that many of us league veterans will remember. But now he is a combination of the first and second iteration, combining humanity with godly powers. It is a wonderful narrative of a man who resents the gods but uses their powers. He is not truly just a human and I love the potential inner struggles and conflicts he has with himself. These are wonderful sources of character growth, something Pantheon direly needed in my opinion. I am happy that Pantheon is more than a jacked angry dude with a spear now. Hes finally a compelling and intricate character while still remaining faithful to his very roots. 

The only issue I have with the rework is the lack of sunshine in this bread loving warriors life. 
I think its obvious what I am getting at. I really liked that Pantheon and Leona were childhood friends back in the day and really was unsatisfied that they got ripped apart the way they did. From friends to being estranged and now to enemies, its the only story development that saddened me as Pantheons contempt seems to be mostly directed at Leona (and Aatrox) if voice lines are to be believed. 

I can't really see why Pantheon would despise her so much. Is it not her duty to protect the people of the mountain as leader of the Solari? In Leonas short story she defended the mountain against invaders, in Pantheons lore story he defended the mountain which was besieged by Aatrox. They both clearly work towards the same goal with overlapping motives, the protection of their people. I understand that Pantheon has a great aversion towards the gods after what was done to him and is angered that Leona did nothing against the barbarians, only to later find out that Aatrox was the real threat all along. Yet in his one line towards her he insists that she is stronger than she knows without aspect and armor. Id really want to know what their exact relationship is now and how it could evolve. Would he help her for the good of Targons people? He aided the Ra'Horak, which are under her command. Where does he draw the line? Would he help her soldiers but not Leona herself if she needed his help just because she is an aspect? 

Do you think that expanding their story is something we could expect in the future? With Pantheons lore now updated is there any chance for progression in their story and/or relationship? Targon is such a interesting place and id love to see its two oldest champions interact more and hopefully grow past their misunderstandings.The amount of fan art for the two of them leads me to believe that I am not the only one who liked those two teaming up. What better way to defend the people of Targon then by joining forces? 

Congratulations and all the best to 10 years League of Legends! Here's to another wonderful 10 years!

Yes, a lot of the planned relationship details between Pantheon and Leona had to be cut, unfortunately, to keep things simple and short enough to ship as a bio. 

But personally, I think Pantheon has come out on the other side of a life-changing (and even life-ending) experience. He'd probably  be more open now when it comes to Leona. That line is meant to show he doesn't hate her for who she is, he is frustrated because he sees who he thinks she could be. Who she might _already be_. 

Sometimes we're blinded by our prejudices, and our pasts.

How strong would you say Pantheon is compared to the other Aspects?

I’ve always imagined the Aspects would look like the fights in Fate/Apocrypha. So over the top, so epic

Pantheon's peaks are maybe higher than any other Aspect. I mean, he falls, flaming, from the heavens. But his lows are lower. At the end of the day, he's only a man. So in a fight between Pantheon and any Aspect or Darkin, expect him to take a bit of a beating. The question is whether he can hold it together long enough to strike a blow that carries all his rage, will, and belief.

Can we redo some of Shyvanas lore and bring back her father? There are elements I love from the new lore, but the old one was so powerful. Yvva needing to wait for the rest of her clutch was an awesome addition, but I feel like removing Shyvanas father was a huge blow. 

The thief makes no sense and really doesn't fulfill the role of sacrificing himself to save Shyvana from her mother.  

Yvva has no reason told in the story why she wants to attack Shvyana.

I love Shyvana (in case you couldn't tell lol).

Can you also explain what the narrative team meant when they said Shyvanas lore was wrong on the website those 5 years and the master never matched? 

Thanks!

Ah, I don't have much knowledge about what happened with the recent Shyvana changes, unfortunately. But I can give you my perspective as a member of Champions team.

Redoing lore is hard, and redoing the redoing of lore even harder. Pantheon is the first champ I worked on who already had a post-Summoners reboot, and I personally made it my mission not to change anything I didn't have to, otherwise... what's real? I hope the things that some people didn't like right away ended up becoming meaningful parts of a bigger story.

In other words, it's starting to get really hard to make changes, and so it's important to make the right ones at the right time. I love updating lore when we do VGUs because it's a chance to take a step back and ask, "who is this character really? Why do I want to be them for 30+ minutes at  a time?"

Shyvana has come really, really close to getting a VGU, on Reav3's last poll. While I can't guarantee any changes, if she does get a VGU that might be on the table.

Thank you. Please really do consider it.

I'd love to see Shyvana and A Sol interact one day as well. Really, anyone interacting with Aurelion Sol would be cool. He has a lot of interesting things to say but all of his conversations are one sided. I want to see him challenged. I want to see what he truly is, beneath the arrogance and cool.

Thanks again for bringing Shyvana up, I'll pass your thoughts on to others in narrative.

Very early on, there was a child involved in Atreus's backstory, who he had to rescue and mentor a la Wolverine and X-23. She helped make Pantheon's story simpler to understand, in a way. Protecting mortals is maybe harder to relate to than protecting a child, and the latter can symbolize the former. 

But it was distracting and adding complication to a backstory that I was already struggling to boil down. We have word count limitations, etc. It was also no one's favorite thing. So we pivoted on that pretty quickly, it was only in the mix a week or so. I think Iula and the farm have come to serve the same purpose in the story, in a way that flows better.

It says a lot that I didn't even remember we tried this until I dove into some docs.

Pantheon is still just a man, albeit a stubborn one, with enough willpower to set spear alight. His whole society is built around ideas he doesn't agree with, and they hold to these fervently (it's a religion). I don't think the Solari would be too pleased to see a mortal man wielding the panoply of an Aspect. And the Aspects and Darkin are still out there. He's clashed twice with Aatrox, and you have to wonder how these events might drive Aatrox to take action as well.

Most recently, he's been drawn to Shurima (seen in his short story), where Ascended are starting to fight and bring mass death and destruction again.

Tldr, he's going to be busy.
